Guidelines should be able to account for people's individual circumstances and thereby grant them access to a second loan within a 12-month period if it is deemed to be appropriate and of genuine need. This would ensure that the scheme did not get out of control and yet, at the same time, would provide a much needed safety net. Commonsense, I believe, must prevail.

I take encouragement from comments by the minister, the Hon. Senator Newman, that she would consider future changes in light of ongoing experiences. I believe that it is time that we re-examine this legislation to accommodate the genuine needs of less fortunate people in our community. This scheme provides a useful source of emergency funds for families in our community. Let us not forget that it is often the children that this money helps. I urgently call on our government to act on these concerns and to make the necessary legislative changes.

While I am on my feet I would like to briefly remark on the comments of the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) with regard to primary schools. It is very sad if that is in fact the case with public schools in Tasmania. I was quite disturbed by what he had to say. However, a lot of the primary schools that we have in my electorate are certainly not in that situation. In fact, we have some wonderful kids coming out of those schools and going on to public high schools. Schools like Whitfield and the new one at Kuranda have the most magnificent structures. In Kuranda in particular the outlook over the rainforest is just absolutely superb and certainly will go a long way to encouraging the kids to maximise their skills. Even in schools in Cooktown and on Thursday Island they turn out a great result. We are talking all public schools; we are not talking private schools. They do a great job. At times I am sure funding can be tight.

I am also a product of a public school—Mareeba State School. I am certainly very familiar with a lot of the comments that the member made with regard to reflection, but I have to say that even my own children, who also went through the public school system, were not in any way disadvantaged by that. I would like to put in a plug, particularly for those in my area, for the great work that they do and the wonderful kids that they turn out into the public secondary schools. Those kids can compete with the best of them and the private schools are having to work very hard to be able to compete with our local public schools.

talk.start.para: —My grievance relates to the government's continuing poor performance on employment and training. But I also want to take up an issue raised by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch)—and I note his being a product of the local schools in Mareeba. I only wish he had stood up for the community of Mareeba when his government, the Howard government, closed the CES as one of its first decisions to withdraw services in regional Australia.

speech.para: I also understand that many disadvantaged people live from week to week without any real savings. In that context, as the federal member for Batman, I understand the needs of pensioners, many of whom do not have savings and live from week to week. I wish the member for Leichhardt would make a similar speech about the need for this government to reverse its disastrously bad decision to withdraw reasonable dental services for the underprivileged people in my electorate, many of whom are pensioners or unemployed living from week to week. The truth of the matter is that dental services are a luxury when you live on a pension or on unemployment benefits. That is a problem that this government has to face up to, in the same way it has to face up to its deteriorating record on the issue of jobs.

That takes me to John Howard's first two years as Prime Minister. Those first two years have shown that total jobs growth has been little more than one-third of that which occurred in the last two years of the former Labor government—and I note the member for Leichhardt scurrying from the House so as not to hear of the bad performance of the Howard government on the issue of jobs.

The number of full-time jobs has grown by less than one quarter of the number created in the last two years of Labor. In these same two years the unemployment rate has barely fallen, whereas it had been falling rapidly under Labor. The youth unemployment rate has not improved at all, despite the Prime Minister's promise that his highest priority would be to reduce it. That promise was made in the last week of the election campaign in his speech to the National Press Club.

People's lack of hope of finding jobs under John Howard shows up in the fall in the number of people participating in the search for work. Since the Prime Minister's election, the participation rate is down by more than half a percentage point—from 63.8 per cent to 63.2 per cent. I find it strange that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) does not like to answer questions about these facts in question time.

That takes me to the reference made earlier today by the minister for employment about new figures released by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research. As is the minister's habit, he was very selective in his use of these figures. He did not, for example, mention that these figures show that after two years of the Howard government `traditional trade based apprenticeship commencements appear to be at a four-year low'. The new figures show that the number of apprenticeships has in fact fallen by more than 5,000 since Labor's last full year in office. This is directly due to the Howard government's cuts in payment of incentives to employers who do the responsible thing and make a commitment to longer term training.

Today's figures also show that, while their numbers are still rising—and this is the key point—the rate of growth in shorter term traineeships has also fallen off sharply. This is the truth of the matter: yes, the trend to increase the number of traineeships in Australia has continued to increase, but the real problem is the fall off in the growth of traineeships. On this point I make the following factual statement: the growth rate of traineeships has fallen from 146 per cent in 1995-96 to less than half this—just 61 per cent—in 1996-97. These are facts that the minister for employment does not like raised in this House.

The falling rate of traineeship growth is due to the failure of this government to continue the cooperative efforts by the Labor government, business and unions, through Nettforce, to actively promote placement of people into training. This government has cut investment in skills training and dismantled successful cooperative efforts to improve young people's skills. Yet at the same time—and this is the crux of the problem—skill shortages continue to grow in key areas of the economy which are crying out for the development of our young people's talents.

Madam Deputy Speaker, what is this government's answer to that problem? As you well know, it is to bring in skilled workers from overseas rather than train Australia's unemployed. That is the government's solution to growing skill shortages in Australia. The government is condemned—and so it ought to be—by the mums and dads of Australia who are worried about their young, worried about decent training and job opportunities.

Why didn't the minister for employment tell us about his own department's new publication, which was also released today, showing growing skill shortages in the very trades where apprenticeship numbers are falling—numbers having fallen, for example, in the traditional apprenticeships by more than 5,000 since Labor's last year in office? I will tell you why: because the minister knows that this evidence highlights the policy failings of the Howard government, its short-sightedness and failure to plan for our kids' future. To my way of thinking, our kids' future is more important than bringing in skilled workers from overseas to take jobs that ought to be filled by Australians.

The Howard government has acted to punish young people for unemployment by taking away their payments. But it has done nothing to construct pathways for them into quality jobs for the future. To make matters worse, the number of people out of work for more than one year shot up by nearly 60,000 in the 16 months following the Howard government's first cuts to Labor's jobs and training programs. This, I suggest, has added some $½ billion to budget outlays on unemployment benefits and has deprived the Australian economy on a long-term basis of the vital skills and energies of these potential workers.

More and more Australians are also feeling less and less secure, less and less comfortable about keeping their jobs. That is because of the Howard government's lack of interest in managing the international forces of economic change to protect Australian workers. The government ignored the plight of the steelworkers in Newcastle, and it has cut programs designed to help them and other retrenched workers find new jobs and receive the income support to which they are entitled.

Currently, the entire system of employment services is also in disarray, due to the government's determination to privatise the Commonwealth Employment Service and shut down experienced community based agencies such as Skillshare. The new, greatly reduced arrangements for helping job seekers find and prepare for work have destroyed the 50-year tradition of a free universal public employment service in Australia.

The new system of Dr Kemp and the Prime Minister means that only people on unemployment benefits can get real help to find work. This excludes hundreds of thousands of others who used to be helped under Labor, including women whose husbands or partners have jobs. The handing out of the $1.7 billion taken from the public and community employment service providers to the new, mostly private companies has been marked by incompetence and scandal—remember the Khadar Roude story—as has been the case with so much of the other public money handed out by Howard government ministers.

The new arrangements for payments to private providers have been described by independent observers as `ripe for exploitation'. The only program which the Howard government has introduced to make up for the many programs which it has abolished is the work for the dole scheme, which makes a small proportion of the young unemployed do a couple of days work a week for a few months with no skills training to improve their future prospects of finding real jobs. I emphasise that—no skills training.

The Howard government has also abandoned urban and regional centres with particularly high unemployment, such as the Northern Rivers of New South Wales and Wide Bay, closing down government offices and removing programs designed to help declining regions find new and positive futures. An energetic role for government in generating employment is what will distinguish Labor's approach from the Howard government, which has idly presided over a stagnation of economic jobs growth and, as a result, entrenched high unemployment in Australia.

I go finally to the question of employment vacancies. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) referred last week to the ABS data. In the two years from February 1996-98—that is, since the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was elected—job vacancies have risen 18 per cent. In the previous two years—1994-96—under Labor they rose by 40 per cent. They are the real facts, not the situation that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and others would seek to present in a distorted way to this House.

It is about training and jobs for Australia, not about relying on skilled migration at the expense of Australia's unemployed or relying on skilled migration at the expense of our young people. Mums and dads are concerned. They want an investment in training Australians, especially young unemployed Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I had the opportunity and good fortune, like many of my colleagues will have had, to open a school extension two weeks ago in my electorate in the town of Warrnambool. This was an extension at the St Joseph's Parish Primary School. I was very taken, while I was doing this very pleasant duty, to note the St Joseph's vision and mission statement. When I was looking at this statement, I noticed around the border it had many of the values that not only the school aspires to teach the children but also most people in the community would see as the sorts of values that we would like to inculcate not only in the young of Australia but also right throughout Australia in all people.

speech.para: As I was reading those I thought, `What a contrast to some of the values that are being pushed towards everyone'—but the young in particular, and the most vulnerable people are the young—`whenever they turn on the television set or go to watch one of the modern movies.' When we look at some of those values—and they are written around the border; I could start anywhere—they are not only the sorts of values that the young can take up but also the sorts of values that will serve them very well throughout their lives.

We see values like hope. I think everyone likes to have hope for the future. There is the value of faith. There is no doubt that many studies have shown that faith is a very powerful part of human development. There is the value of tolerance. The fact that we do have a tolerant society is something that all Australians are very proud of. It may not be as tolerant as we would like, but it is still a value we should aspire to. There are the values of service and consideration for others. I think they are all values that would help make for a better community.

If we look at some of the others, there is the value of self worth—obviously something the school wants to develop. There is dignity—a value that all of us would like to see developed in the next generation. There is respect—something which is often taught amongst the younger generation but not so often practised amongst the older generation. There is trust—and I think all of us would like to believe that trust is still a very important value in life. There is joy—and I think that is self-evident. There is responsibility—obviously schools want to develop the understanding of responsibility.

If we keep going there is reconciliation—a word that has a special meaning in today's political climate, but one that has a much wider application when we look at what it can mean throughout families, throughout communities and, indeed, between nations. Then there are other values like: love, peace, justice, compassion, cooperation, community, care, concern, support, forgiveness—all very important values. I commend the school for promoting and teaching them throughout the years that students are at that school, and no doubt other schools try to do the same thing in different ways.

What a comparison that is to an article which was in yesterday's Sunday Age. It points out what an extraordinary contrast the young of this generation and recent generations of Australians and the recent generations in other countries are facing when you look at what their schools are trying to teach them, what their parents are trying to teach them and what they are picking up from what is recognised as one of the most powerful mediums the world has ever seen—that is, television.

It is pointed out in this article that the term `television intoxication' was first used some years ago back in 1977 in a court case when a 15-year-old Florida boy shot and killed an 82-year-old neighbour—something that brings immediate memories of more recent events. This article was written by Professor Michael Carr-Gregg, a psychologist and head of the education and training unit of the Centre for Adolescent Health at the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne—someone holding a very responsible and highly respected position in Melbourne. The article says:

Although few psychologists would agree that excessive television viewing can exculpate a murderer, a huge body of evidence—including 3000 studies before 1971 alone—suggests a strong connection between television watching and aggression.

I think this is quite frightening. It is not new, but it does reiterate something that I think many of us have been aware of but to date have had limited effect in trying to counter. It goes on to say:
One of the first such studies, in 1956—
that is 40 years ago—

compared the behaviour of two groups of four-year-olds. One watched a Woody Woodpecker cartoon containing many acts of violence, the other group a non-violent cartoon, The Little Red Hen . The Woody watchers were more likely to hit other children, break toys and be generally destructive.

This is not new; this was something that was done over 40 years ago. Following that, the article goes on to talk about some of the work that was done in America under President Johnson by his National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence. It looks at some of the findings of what was to become the Cultural Indicators project, which it points out is:
. . . the longest-running continuous media-research undertaking in the world.
It goes on to say:
The findings from the 30-year Cultural Indicators project are simply astonishing.
These are the article's words: `simply astonishing.' The article goes on:

According to the research, the average American couch potato is confronted with a veritable smorgasbord of violent behaviour. On average, there are more than five violent scenes in an hour of prime time, and five murders a night.
These are staggering figures. The article continues:
Most disturbingly, there are 25 violent acts an hour in Saturday morning cartoons—the programs most watched by children, usually without supervision.
These are amazing statistics; an amazing reflection on what is happening in our community. It goes on to say:

The Centre for Media and Public Affairs examined violence on free-to-air and cable channels and counted 2605 acts of violence on just one day, the majority occurring in the early morning when children were most likely to be watching.
And we wonder why we have some problems in the community these days. It goes on:

By the reckoning of the Cultural Indicators project, the average American child will have witnessed more than 8000 murders and 100,000 other violent acts on television by the time he or she leaves primary school.
That is primary school; not secondary school. This is staggering stuff. The article goes on to talk about a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association which found:
. . . the typical American child spends 27 hours a week watching television and will witness 40,000 murders and 200,000 other violent acts by the age of 18.

Of course, we know that Australian children are not that different from American children and a lot of the programming that we now get in Australia is American programming. It is quite clear that Australian children's lives have never before been so filled with full colour images of violence. Clearly, whatever way you measure it, the results are always the same. The article goes on to point out:

The jury on the effects of TV violence has returned and the verdict is that young people so exposed can become immune to the horror of violence, may gradually accept violence as a way to solve problems, may imitate the violence they observe on television and in some instances may over-identify with certain characters, victims and/or victimisers.

It all sounds so familiar; it all sounds so tragic. When we look at films like Terminator or Rambo , we can see the sort of role model that is developing amongst people—that real men are violent, real men kill their enemies and so on. Yet, what are we doing about it? Going back to the values from the St Joseph's school that I identified at the beginning, I think this really does show that we as a community are doing a very poor job in the way that we are approaching the education of the next generation—in their upbringing, in the way that we are, on the one hand, asking our schools to develop with parents the right values and, on the on the other hand, allowing television and other films to develop a totally different set of values. Is it any wonder that we have so many wanton acts of violence occurring in the community today? Is it any wonder that we are seeing some of the dreadful scenes of kids going out there with guns and so on? Is it any wonder that we as a community have to have a long hard look at ourselves and ask: what are we doing? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week, I had the opportunity in this place to make some comments about the policy issue of whether or not the rest of Telstra should be sold and the company totally privatised. In this grievance debate I would like to say some more about it, with a particular focus: that is, what I call the rural cross-subsidy and the direct consequences of the conflict of interest that arises when Telstra is wholly owned by private shareholders versus when it is majority owned by the government—as is now the case and as Labor is committed to maintaining.

speech.para: To develop this point, I should explain those two concepts. When Telstra is either wholly owned by the government or majority owned by the government it is bound to take direction from the government about a range of things, including where it invests, where it provides its services, what prices it can charge, what are its obligations to help develop industry, what are the relationships it has with the rest of the world—for instance, for international trunk calls—who should get the Internet, and what sort of technology should be made available in Australia. Telstra, as the major communications company in Australia—so much bigger and so much more dominant than anyone else—is the driver of all these decisions.

When a government has the controlling interest it says, for instance, `I know with new technology you have now got too many staff and you may need to have less staff over time.' But, as happened under Labor, when Telstra proposed that old technology was no longer relevant and not as many people would be required for switchboards or whatever, there was a gradual phasing down of the number of jobs over a five-year period. What has now been proposed by the Telstra board is that 20,000 jobs be shed in two years. Many of those jobs are in country areas. Where a Labor government would say, `No, shedding 20,000 jobs just like that is not on; let's have a look at a plan that manages it for people in a much better way', that is not the message they now get. That is an example, and it goes right across the board.

So, governments own or control these organisations for specific reasons. The conflict of interest I mentioned before relates to profits for the shareholder versus profits for the government. If Telstra is wholly owned by private shareholders then they have only one interest, and that is maximising the returns on their shareholdings—getting the best possible profit and dividends to them as shareholders.

You hope that country people can have mobile phones that work as well, and cover as big an area, as those in the city. But there is a very simple equation. It costs a certain amount of money for Telstra to set up the towers, signals and infrastructure in the cities so that city people can pick up a mobile phone and have it work anywhere. There are literally millions of customers right around the corner who can hook straight onto that network and pay their monthly phone bill. Telstra makes very high profits out of those city users. But, if they go out into country areas and set up towers, where the same amount of area reaches only, say, 1,000 customers instead of 50,000 customers, Telstra runs that service at a loss.

When you have private shareholders, the private shareholders say to the manager, `What are you doing investing good money out there when you are running at a loss? Those profits that you make in the city you should be returning to us as dividends on our investment.' If the government has ownership, or the majority ownership, of Telstra it can say, `Some of those profits made in the city must be used to pay for facilities that are developed in the less profitable areas in the country.' That is what the cross-subsidy is: the profits made in the city are used to provide services for people in the country.

In 1986 the communications minister at the time, Mr Duffy, had this analysed, and the figure is quite dramatic. The Bureau of Transport Economics worked out that the value of that cross-subsidy was $500 million a year to provide for those rural services. But that was just for phones. We are now talking about untimed or timed local calls; we are talking about mobile phones; we are talking about the Internet; we are talking about a whole range of new technology. I would postulate that the 1986 figure of $500 million is at least $1 billion now. That is what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is asking people to accept—that is, under his proposal those private shareholders who would totally own Telstra would be happy to see $1 billion of their profits being used to pay for unprofitable services every year in the country. That is just nonsense.

I noticed an article about a National Party conference late last month at which the National Party demanded guarantees from the Prime Minister that, if Telstra was fully privatised, these rural communications services would be upgraded and protected. I thought to myself, `I wonder whether they even understand how much is involved here.' Guess what? Out came the figure from the Prime Minister's office of about $30 million. We are talking about $1 billion, not $30 million. Here is the catch that these rural politicians from the government side need to understand.

I am very pleased to see in the chamber today the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) because I know he actually understands this. There is a very direct parallel between the sugar tariff and the guarantee on telecommunications services. People in areas such as the seats of Leichhardt, Capricornia, Dawson, Herbert, Page and Richmond, represented by members like Mr Entsch, Mr Marek, Mrs De-Anne Kelly, Mr Lindsay, Mr Causley, and Mr Anthony, all were promised unequivocally by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) that their sugar tariff would stay—no ifs, no buts. Then it was taken away. To his great credit, the member for Kennedy was the only one on that side who promised his constituents that he would vote to keep their sugar tariff and carried out his word in the chamber. The rest of them went missing in action. They did not stand up.

I am saying that, when it comes to the crunch on Telstra, the promises on Telstra are worth about as much as were the promises on sugar. If these people cannot stand up to Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, and Peter Costello, the Treasurer, on the sugar tariff, where on earth do people think they are going to find the courage to stand up on Telstra? We have a very significant point to discuss in this parliament—that is, what are the guarantees that would be given to cover $1 billion a year of rural cross-subsidy, which will surely disappear, and how can they be guaranteed and delivered by people who could not even stand up on the sugar tariff?
I draw the attention of the House to a lovely cartoon in the Courier-Mail. It starts off with a fellow phoning Telstra. This is what he is told:
`Welcome! To the fully privatised Telstra . . .
. . . If you're a shareholder press one and you will be attended to instantly . . .
. . . If you're a big business user . . . press two and you will be answered shortly . . .
. . . If you're a small business user press three and you will be answered eventually . . .
. . . If you are just any old domestic user press four and you will be put on hold as this is a timed call . . .
. . . And lastly if you're a remote area rural user . . . you are a drain on profits . . . Press 5 and you will be disconnected immediately . . .

That is the fact of it. This rural cross-subsidy is going to become a huge election issue. I am signalling in the parliament now that talk about figures like $30 million takes us nowhere. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Areas: Loss of Services—Population Decline

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), put up a fight about Telstra, which I think is a very good thing for the opposition to be doing. That is what oppositions are about. There is no doubt in my mind that we are going to have enormous difficulty—however good the government's intentions are and those of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—seeing those commitments being enforced. A mechanism for enforcing those community service obligations is vitally important to the people of outback Australia.

speech.para: I rose recently in this House to speak about population and to ask this House: is the government of Australia—when I say government, I mean that in a general sense; not only talking about the government of the present moment but the government in the future and the government in the past—serious about settling this continent? When Captain Cook arrived on this continent, there were about 300,000 people living here, but even now 90 per cent of the continent of Australia does not have many more than 300,000 people living in it.

As fundamental, prerequisite services are removed from country areas, then the population must follow. A little town, Julia Creek, where I did a lot of my business in my days before going into parliament, is a town now bereft of a high school, bereft of a clerk of the court and bereft of its Catholic primary school; a town that has lost service after service. The neighbouring town of Cloncurry, a much bigger town, lost six separate services in the space of one year. Julia Creek now is facing the loss of its railway gang, which is very serious indeed.

I was rung up from Julia Creek this week. The guns issue has already raised its ugly head. On that issue, the biggest industry west of the Great Dividing Range—outside the mining industry, which is rapidly ceasing to be an outback industry of Australia because of the fly-ins: it is now a city based industry; and miners do not live in these areas—is the kangaroo shooting industry, which is now a bigger employer than the wool industry. I cannot speak with authority about that for south-west Queensland but I certainly can for the central west, the north-west and the mid-west of North Queensland, and the Gulf country. That is a very sad reflection upon the economic rationalist policies of the last 10 years under the Labor government; and I regret to say some of those policies are continuing.

Three shooters in the area recently had a visit from the police for reasons that we have never discovered. Three rifles were there with the bolts in them. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you are a roo shooter, your rifle is your tool of trade; it is like having the keys in the car or like having the computer turned on if you are an accountant. This is their place of work. For these men to have lost their livelihood, and some of their families have been in the game for two or three generations, is very serious stuff indeed. The dislocations and the punishment upon the people of outback Australia are being felt right at this very moment.

We have lost 38 per cent of our population from the central west. I nominate the shires of Longreach, Blackall, Barcaldine, Aramac, Muttaburra and Winton. In the mid-west area of North Queensland—that is, if you like, the north-west excluding Mount Isa—in the towns of Cloncurry, Julia Creek, Richmond and Hughenden, we have lost 42 per cent of our population. The population of Mount Isa, a mining town, has declined from about 30,000 to around 20,000. Every single western statistical division in the last census showed a population loss once again.

We must ask the question: do we seriously want to stay in occupation of this continent? I repeat to the House: if you get on an aeroplane in Townsville and you fly across to Broome, you look out either side of that aeroplane and you will see no sign of human habitation, yet you have just flown over three-quarters of the nation's water resources and two-thirds of the nation's arable land, populated by 100,000 people; an area that could support a population, quite literally, of 100 million people, because that is where Australia's water supply is, that is where Australia's flat farmland is and that is where there are no Australians.

If there is a commitment by the government of Australia to populate these areas, under present concepts I am sorry but I cannot see it. For the last 15 years, all we have seen is a roll back. You simply must act positively. You cannot simply glide along on a user-pays policy. There were magnificent achievements in the Menzies and McEwen era, where we saw the beef road schemes, dry strips of bitumen into every single nook and cranny throughout Australia. At one recent poll taken of what the most effective weapon was in Australia for fighting drought, what was nominated was not water schemes, not water conservation schemes, not financial assistance through taxation arrangements—none of those things—the beef road scheme was named.

For those people who have long denigrated the Ord: on the last figures I saw, the Ord is now paying for itself every eight years. At its present rate of development it will be paying for itself every four years, just out of tax revenue. If you want to talk about the cost of building it in terms of today's money and the benefits flowing from that scheme, it is most certainly paying for itself every three or four years. But even allowing for just the narrow analysis of the tax benefit flowing to this government from the production out of that area, we are talking about that project paying for itself every eight years.

A government is an institution, the same as a corporation. If someone comes along to a corporation and says, `I can show you a 300 per cent return on invested capital,' then you would be very foolish not to take up that offer, if in fact it is a true and serious offer.

I come into this place and put before the House the issue of the Hells Gate dam scheme. Some ministers will be part of the Federation Fund. Some of them will be sitting in a room making a decision about where the money made from the sale of Telstra will go. If we are to take a very serious negative with the sale of Telstra, I would plead with the government to give in return a very important positive. The Hells Gate dam scheme will cost $405 million. The state government of Queensland has projected that the income that will be generated by that scheme will be $740 million a year. The figure projected by the North Queensland Economic Development Zone Board, which is jointly financed by this government, the last Labor government and the Queensland government, also quotes a figure of $740 million a year. So for an outlay of $405 million, the people of Australia will benefit to the extent of $740 million every single year forever.

The honourable member for Page (Mr Causley) quotes a figure that the New England University claims is a five to one multiplier effect with irrigation projects. Not only do we derive that benefit but we also derive the benefit of the value saved to the Australian taxpayers by not having to pay the unemployed.

During the Great Depression in the United States some 16 per cent of the population was unemployed. I dare say that the real unemployment figure today is much higher than the eight or nine per cent which is constantly quoted. Dr Kemp, the current Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, quoted a figure of 19 per cent, and I do not think he was very far out. During the Depression, America had an unemployment rate of 16 per cent and built the magnificent Tennessee Valley Authority projects which have yielded so much benefit for that nation forever. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! I put the question:

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
(1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (after line 9), before section 51AD, insert:
(1) In this Part:
applicable industry code , in relation to a corporation that is a participant in an industry, means:
(a) the prescribed provisions of any mandatory industry code relating to the industry; and
(b) the prescribed provisions of any voluntary industry code that binds the corporation.
consumer , in relation to an industry, means a person to whom goods or services are or may be supplied by participants in the industry.
industry code means a code regulating the conduct of participants in an industry towards other participants in the industry or towards consumers in the industry.
mandatory industry code means an industry code that is declared by regulations under section 51AE to be mandatory.
voluntary industry code means an industry code that is declared by regulations under section 51AE to be voluntary.

(2) For the purposes of this Part, a voluntary industry code binds a person who has agreed, as prescribed, to be bound by the code and who has not subsequently ceased, as prescribed, to be bound by it.
(3) To avoid doubt, it is declared that:
(a) franchising is an industry for the purposes of this Part; and
(b) franchisors and franchisees are participants in the industry of franchising, whether or not they are also participants in another industry.
(2) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 13) to page 4 (line 3), omit subsections (2) and (3).
(3) Schedule 2, item 2, page 6 (lines 11 to 18), omit subsections (1) and (2), substitute:
(1) A corporation must not, in trade or commerce, in connection with:
(a) the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a person (other than a listed public company); or
(b) the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services from a person (other than a listed public company);
engage in conduct that is, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
(2) A person must not, in trade or commerce, in connection with:
(a) the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a corporation (other than a listed public company); or
(b) the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services from a corporation (other than a listed public company);
engage in conduct that is, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
(4) Schedule 2, item 2, page 7 (after line 34), after subsection (3), insert:

(3A) Without in any way limiting the matters to which the Court may have regard for the purpose of determining whether a corporation or a person (the acquirer ) has contravened subsection (1) or (2) in connection with the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services from a person or corporation (the small business supplier ), the Court may have regard to:
(a) the relative strengths of the bargaining positions of the acquirer and the small business supplier; and

(b) whether, as a result of conduct engaged in by the acquirer, the small business supplier was required to comply with conditions that were not reasonably necessary for the protection of the legitimate interests of the acquirer; and
(c) whether the small business supplier was able to understand any documents relating to the acquisition or possible acquisition of the goods or services; and

(d) whether any undue influence or pressure was exerted on, or any unfair tactics were used against, the small business supplier or a person acting on behalf of the small business supplier by the acquirer or a person acting on behalf of the acquirer in relation to the acquisition or possible acquisition of the goods or services; and
(e) the amount for which, and the circumstances in which, the small business supplier could have supplied identical or equivalent goods or services to a person other than the acquirer; and

(f) the extent to which the acquirer's conduct towards the small business supplier was consistent with the acquirer's conduct in similar transactions between the acquirer and other like small business suppliers; and
(g) the requirements of any applicable industry code; and
(h) the requirements of any other industry code, if the small business supplier acted on the reasonable belief that the acquirer would comply with that code; and
(i) the extent to which the acquirer unreasonably failed to disclose to the small business supplier:
(i) any intended conduct of the acquirer that might affect the interests of the small business supplier; and

(ii) any risks to the small business supplier arising from the acquirer's intended conduct (being risks that the acquirer should have foreseen would not be apparent to the small business supplier); and
(j) the extent to which the acquirer was willing to negotiate the terms and conditions of any contract for the acquisition of the goods and services with the small business supplier; and
(k) the extent to which the acquirer and the small business supplier acted in good faith.
(5) Schedule 2, item 2, page 7 (line 35) to page 8 (line 3), omit subsection (4), substitute:
(4) A person is not to be taken for the purposes of this section to engage in unconscionable conduct in connection with:
(a) the supply or possible supply of goods or services to another person; or
(b) the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services from another person;

by reason only that the first-mentioned person institutes legal proceedings in relation to that supply, possible supply, acquisition or possible acquisition or refers to arbitration a dispute or claim in relation to that supply, possible supply, acquisition or possible acquisition.

(6) Schedule 2, item 2, page 8 (lines 5 to 8), omit "in connection with the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a person, or whether a person has contravened subsection (2) in connection with the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a corporation:", substitute "or whether a person has contravened subsection (2):".
(7) Schedule 2, item 2, page 8 (after line 19), after subsection (6), insert:

(6A) A reference in this section to the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services is a reference to the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services by a person whose acquisition or possible acquisition of the goods or services is or would be for the purpose of trade or commerce.
(8) Schedule 2, item 2, page 8 (after line 23), after subsection (7), insert:

(7A) A reference in this section to the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services does not include a reference to the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services at a price in excess of $1,000,000, or such higher amount as is prescribed.
(9) Schedule 2, item 2, page 8 (lines 24 to 31), omit subsection (8), substitute:
(8) For the purposes of subsections (7) and (7A):
(a) subject to paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e), the price for:
(i) the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a person; or
(ii) the acquisition or possible acquisition of goods or services by a person;
is taken to be the amount paid or payable by the person for the goods or services; and
(b) paragraph 4B(2)(c) applies as if references in that paragraph to the purchase of goods or services by a person were references to:
(i) the supply of goods or services to a person pursuant to a purchase; or

as the case requires; and
(c) paragraph 4B(2)(d) applies as if:

(i) the reference in that paragraph to a person acquiring goods or services otherwise than by way of purchase included a reference to a person being supplied with goods or services otherwise than pursuant to a purchase; and
(ii) a reference in that paragraph to acquisition included a reference to supply; and

(d) paragraph 4B(2)(e) applies as if references in that paragraph to the acquisition of goods or services by a person, or to the acquisition of services by a person, included references to the supply of goods or services to a person, or the supply of services, to a person, as the case may be; and

(e) the price for the supply or possible supply, or the acquisition or possible acquisition, of services comprising or including a loan or loan facility is taken to include the capital value of the loan or loan facility.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

In moving that motion, I seek the concurrence of the House to the amendments which have been passed by the Senate to the package of measures contained in the government's Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 . The measures which have now returned to the House are the government amendments in the Senate.

I am pleased to be able to say to the House that all the other amendments—namely, those moved by the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Independents—were in each and every case lost in the Senate. The government's amendments in each and every case were supported by the Senate. Today is an historic occasion in the federal parliament because by the end of today's business we will have seen through the parliament the historic reforms announced by the government in our New Deal: Fair Deal package last September.

The new law in the Trade Practices Act will give to small business for the first time protection throughout Australia against unconscionable conduct by big business. It will also allow the introduction of legally recognised codes of conduct underpinned by the Trade Practices Act, including mandatory codes for small business franchisees in the retail and oil industries. It is a ground-breaking policy development for the benefit of small business. It is the light at the end of the unfair trading tunnel. It sends the strongest message ever from the federal parliament to the Australian business community that commercial relations between big and small businesses must be treated on a fair and reasonable basis.

The purpose of these historic changes is to induce behavioural change in commercial practices so that small businesses do get a fair go and, where they are treated unfairly, they have available to them a means of redress. For the first time real teeth are being provided within Australian law, and to the ACCC, to benefit those small businesses who, because of their unequal bargaining power, are subject to exploitative business conduct.

Small business has been calling for these sorts of reforms for years and years. It was not until the election of the Howard government that the cries of small business for a fair go were finally heard and responded to in a constructive way to the interests of small business. When the previous Labor administration were in office they had report after report. Barren year followed barren year of reports to provide some assistance recommended to them for the small business community, but year after year their cries fell on deaf ears within the Labor Party and small business failed to get the protection which they deserved.

It has taken the commitment of the Howard government, with its strong bias towards the small business community, for these reforms to be achieved. Even the Labor Party admitted as much in the Senate. For example, Senator Schacht, who himself was a Labor small business minister, very kindly said that I had made myself a hero for pushing these reforms through. The Democrats said:
Minister Peter Reith, to his credit, recognised the scope of the problems in small business and has brought forward this bill.

I pay tribute to the parliamentary committee which we promised before the election and which delivered on these issues, chaired by the Liberal member for Bendigo, the Hon. Bruce Reid. It is amazing that, all the way through, the Labor Party, having done nothing for 13 years, were giving advice as to what should be done when they went into opposition. It is amazing that in the Senate they were proposing amendments which even the spokesperson for the Labor Party in the Senate recognised must have been open to some question, seeing that those amendments were being advanced and advocated by representatives of big business supposedly for the benefit of small business. Senator Schacht was remarkably open and frank in his own description of the amendments that the Labor Party were proposing. Thank heavens they did not get up. Thank heavens this government remained determined to the end to ensure a fair deal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We on this side cannot share the enthusiasm of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) for the success that he has achieved in respect of getting this legislation through, for a number of reasons. I am sure during the course of our contribution this evening we will try to get that message across. First and foremost, I think it is important to recognise that the Reid committee, to which the minister referred, did hand down a report. That report made recommendations about a number of specific areas in respect of unfair trading. It made recommendations about unfairness, not unconscionability; unfairness in terms of trading relationships between small business people and others in a trading environment. The government's response was to take the unfairness element, throw it away and say, `That won't work. We're going to talk about unconscionability.' It was an issue that had been examined by this committee, which the minister now lauds, but was set aside as being unworkable.

speech.para: Secondly, of course, one of the major issues that were considered in this was the whole issue of retail tenancy law. Again the minister has set that completely aside; yet the committee, which, I repeat, he lauds in this place—and its chairman, Bruce Reid, the member for Bendigo, and all the other government members should hang their heads in shame on this one—made recommendations about retail tenancy laws. The government completely jumped on those recommendations and just put them to one side. The minister went along to a small business ministers meeting on 5 December last year. He spoke at length to a number of small business organisations and basically said to them, `You take what we're going to put up or we'll give you nothing.' As a consequence, of course, we get qualified support from many of these business organisations for what the government has done.

The opposition has said, `Because of the way this debate has gone and because the government has succeeded in the Senate in getting its watered down version of the legislation in place, a watered down version of the Reid committee report, we support what the government is attempting to do here, although we do not believe it is strong enough.' If the minister thinks that I or indeed the Labor Party might have arrived late on the scene for this, it is a reflection of the fact that this committee that he lauds so mightily around this place brought down, I think in his own words, one of the best reports that we have seen in this place. This side of the House adopted it in full; the government did not. The government, in its legislative program, adopted parts of the report that was brought down in this place. Now it tries to turn around and say that it is responding to the committee's report. It is responding in part to a much weaker and a much watered down version.

You have to laugh. I know the minister is known in some of his press releases for trying to perhaps lead people up the garden path; but, when he talks about the Labor Party delaying the legislation in the Senate or in this place or putting in place a watered down version, you really have to sit back and say, `What is this man talking about?' What we sought to do with our amendments was to simply put in place what the Reid committee had recommended.

There was one other area, and that was of course the $1 million transaction issue. That was an issue that was raised by organisations that he talks about as the big end of town. This was an issue that was raised with small business organisations, by the Property Coun cil of Australia, with a whole range of people. The simple reason is that there are many small businesses that do not get to that threshold of $1 million. In fact they go right past it. They are not going to be caught in this legislation. They are not going to get the opportunity to take an unconscionable conduct case, because they are beyond that $1 million threshold. They are still small businesses and we were trying to bring them in, as were the Australian Democrats through the amendment proposed by Senator Murray. I want to speak a little bit more about that during consideration of these amendments this evening.

But we are not going to be frightened off by what the government is attempting to do with this. We will continue to look at ways in which the small business community can get the benefit of the Reid committee report. We will look at ways to try to keep the government true, honest and correct in every detail of that committee report. Regrettably, we fell one short in the Senate the other evening. It certainly is going to be regretted in the small business community as they understand just what all of this legislation actually means to them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think the sad thing about the—(Quorum formed) The sad thing is that, instead of congratulating the government on achieving these historic reforms, the Labor Party can only stand up and say how much better they would have done if they were in government. Given the fact they did nothing for 13 years, it is a rather hollow claim. Given that in the Senate they supported amendments which would have reduced these benefits to small business, it is a quite incredible claim for the shadow minister to make.

speech.para: The shadow minister caps it off by saying we should have also voted for the opposition's retail tenancy reforms in the Senate. The impact of those reforms would have been to give Australian small businesses not one but two sets of retail tenancy laws. Who would have been entangled in red tape by the setting up of a duplicative system of dual tenancy laws? No-one other than the small business community, who would pay such a heavy price. It was something Labor never proposed when in office. We can only marvel at their hypocrisy to be now proposing it in the Senate as these reforms go through.

For Labor it is catch-up politics because for the first time this government has taken a lead on tenancy laws. We did bring together the state and territory ministers. We have an agreed set of principles. We have taken this debate further than ever contemplated when Labor was in office.

The technical amendments that have gone through are sensible ones. They are consequential drafting amendments and other technical amendments which reflect the intent of the original legislation. This is an historic day for small business. This is a great moment for the small business community. As one leading representative of small business said, this is the best news for small business to come out of Canberra for over 20 years. I commend this bill to the House. It means that our legislative package is on track for 1 July, as promised, as delivered. This government is pro small business and proud of it. This is the best piece of legislation that the small business community has seen for decades. I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —A little earlier we talked about the retail tenancy element of this matter. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) just said that our amendment, if it had been passed, would have delivered two sets of retail tenancy laws. The simple fact is that the Reid committee report recommended there be one set at the national level, which is what we were talking about. We were saying that, if that had have been enacted, if the minister had have used his great silver tongue, his great powers of persuasion, on his state colleagues—
—That's right.

—I am saying it nicely to you; I know how you operate. If the minister spoke to his colleagues at the state level in the same way he speaks to people in the business community, we may have seen what we recommended in our amendments in the Senate: one set of retail tenancy laws that covered retail tenants around Australia. It simply is what the issue is about. To see what small business think, I need go no further than the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, who put out a press release welcoming the passage of the fair trading legislation and saying it is great. But then they said:

speech.para: The area of unfair trading which most affects community pharmacies is around retail tenancy issues. In the Guild's view, there is still insufficient protection for small business from unfair and predatory practices by large landlords in the renegotiations of tenancy agreements.

That is precisely the point that we were making: we wanted to have national laws in place to pick up that very point. As a consequence, we were concerned to see that the passage of the legislation did not include that.

In relation to unconscionable conduct, which is the area the government settled on—it completely overturned the Reid committee's recommendations in terms of unfair conduct—we find that the Small Business Coalition said:
Small business has now been given protection against unconscionable conduct which was highlighted in the Reid Report.

Yes, it was highlighted—but it was not agreed to. The committee report rejected the idea of unconscionability in favour of unfair conduct, which is the point we have been trying to get across to the minister and, might I say, to the government members of the committee, including the chairman, who did all the investigatory work. For 12 months they went out there and listened to people in the small business community, and then they came in with a report which the government says was you-beaut and which the Labor Party adopted in full. The government then came along and said, `You beaut, but we're not going to do it. We're going to water it all down because we can't have uniform retail tenancy laws. We certainly can't have unfair conduct. No, we have to have unconscionable conduct.' They were not going to talk about the way in which some small businesses might be excluded from this. As a consequence, Peter Reith, in his usual style, turned around and said that the Labor Party is trying to water down what the Reid committee recommended. It is the other way around.

talk.start.para: —He was right; he's always right.

—Even the parliamentary secretary, who was with me when this whole issue was being debated out there in the broad community—he heard from retailers about what they wanted: tougher laws but not rammed down their throats by this minister saying in his usual style, `Take it or you'll get nothing'—cannot get away from the fact that this government response is watered down and weak. The Franchise Council of Australia has even said the unconscionable provisions are no good. At the end of the day even they have come out and said they are no good.

speech.para: I simply want to put on the record for once and forever that the Labor Party adopted fully the Reid committee report. We supported every one of those recommendations; the government did not. The government rejected most of those and brought in a watered down bill which has now been through both houses of parliament and to which we are now considering some minor technical amendments. I want people in the small business community to clearly understand that.

Secondly, we on this side of the House did not trade with big business and say we will put in what they want. Rather, we talked to small businesses, small business organisations, retail organisations and landlord organisations—which is probably more than the minister did—because we wanted to get out there and find out what people wanted. As a consequence of that, we heard very clearly at rallies right around this country what small business wanted: the adoption of the Reid committee report.

What would make you laugh, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that when many of these so-called organisations representing small business that were knocking on our doors when the Reid report came down, saying, `Adopt it in full. It's the only way to go,' did not get that, they went to water as well—very quietly, because Peter Reith went and visited them. We do not know what he said but we have an idea.

Only Labor stood up for what the Reid committee report recommended. Only Labor was prepared to go with those amendments, and it was the government that thugged through these changes, these watered down amendments, that we are now considering in this place. (Time expired)

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.31 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the break we were talking about the proposed amendments to the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 moved by the government but more particularly about the whole issue of unfair trading. I want to reaffirm one or two other issues associated with some of the misinformation and blatant disinformation that has been put around by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) in respect of the Labor Party's position on this.

speech.para: One of the furphies that has been peddled through the small business community is that in some way the amendments that we had proposed—that is, the amendments which were carefully considered to faithfully reflect the findings of the Reid committee report in respect of unfair trading and unfair business conduct—were a reflection of other factors. He said that we had delayed and that, by moving these amendments, we were in some way impeding the government's program. The fact of the matter is that that is not the case. The simple fact of the matter is that the legislation which emanated from the Reid committee report—the watered down government version of the Reid committee report—came into this place and was debated on 3 and 4 December last year and subsequently passed this House.

When the legislation went to the Senate the Labor Party denied the minister in that place leave to table his second reading speech and said that he had to read it into Hansard. Peter Reith then ran around and said that in some way we were delaying the implementation and the passage of that legislation, and it simply was not the case. The government itself, at long last, scheduled it for consideration in the Senate only last week. In no way was the opposition impeding, holding up or trying to change substantially the legislation to make it weaker. That was not the case at all; in fact, we were trying to beef the legislation up.

I again say to the minister that, in suggesting that because Labor found the cause of small business through the Reid committee report we should in some way be denigrated for it, we adopted that report in full; the government has not. The government has turned its back on the Reid committee. The chairman, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), and all the other Liberal-National Party members of this place who sat on that committee that brought down a unanimous report recommending unfair trading and recommending issues associated with retail tenancy legislation should all hang their heads in shame because they all supported what Peter Reith ultimately put up: a watered down, weak version of what had been recommended and put together after 12 months of extensive and intensive inquiry by that committee.

We on this side just find it extraordinary that he should criticise us for wanting to ensure that, even though it was the Liberal-National Party government that was ultimately going to have responsibility for acting on it, the legislation that came through did give some real protection and some real power for small business. I say again to the minister that he may talk about the number of inquiries that were held by Labor when in government and claim that nothing was done, but that simply is not the case and he knows that that is a fact. The simple fact of the matter is that when Labor were in government they did act for small business in a number of specific areas. Unlike this minister who, along with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), promised that there would be a reduction of some 50 per cent in the paperwork burden which he cannot possibly deliver, unlike this Prime Minister who has been out in the community parading as the patron saint of small business and promising all sorts of things to them and who is going to impose on them a GST burden where one million people will be turned into the tax collectors for this government, the Labor Party are opposed to those measures.

The legislation that has gone through this place and through the Senate is a watered down, weakened version of what Labor was prepared to support. It is unfortunate that Peter Reith and the cabinet were not prepared to back the member for Bendigo and his committee, which brought down an excellent report. I am sure some of my colleagues will comment further on this particular matter, but I would hope that, once and for all, I have laid to rest the nonsense that the minister has been peddling around the small business community that in some way the Labor Party either delayed or watered down this legislation. We did not under any circumstances do that. We were supporting small business for all the reasons that were outlined in the Reid committee report. It is unfortunate that Peter Reith was able to thug the small business community into accepting a much weaker version of the legislation which otherwise would have had bipartisan support. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Far be it from me to be a killjoy at what is an orgy of self-congratulation on the part of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), but we all understand the way in which the minister for small business is positioning himself as a potential Prime Minister or at least as a potential leader of the Liberal Party by setting himself up as a friend of small business and contrasting himself with the Treasurer (Mr Costello). In that respect, he is onto something. The Treasurer is unashamedly a top end of town man and anyone who gets to have a look at where the Treasurer gets his advice from—and recently, having some responsibilities in the superannuation and business regulation area, I have had the opportunity to see some of the areas where the Treasurer gets his advice from—will see that he is unquestionably a top end of town man, so this does provide some potential room for the minister for small business to pose as a champion of small business. Regrettably, however, what we have finally before the parliament is less than satisfactory from the point of view of small business, and I want to go into that in a moment.

speech.para: However, there are a few things in debating that upset me. I understand that we on this side of the House will have different pers pectives from those on the other side of the House and that those different perspectives are often sincerely held and argued. For example, we think it would be better if Telstra were in public ownership; the government believes that it would be better if Telstra were in private ownership. The government believes that the taxation system would be better with a GST; we do not. We believe that it would have adverse effects on the community. These things can be argued legitimately, but it does annoy me when you see people on the other side of politics blatantly rewriting history and endeavouring to perpetrate falsehoods. Sadly, this area of fair trading and protection of retail tenants is one of those areas.

If you listened to the contribution of the minister for small business before the break, you would get the impression that it was this government which had initiated retail tenancy reform. That is in fact not the case. If you go back to 1995, the former Labor government introduced legislation to deal with problems of unconscionable conduct. I recall quite well the former minister for small business, Chris Schacht, announcing those changes and introducing that legislation, as someone who had received a lot of representations from small businesses, from retail tenants, and who was anxious to see some justice for them, noting that the government had done the right thing and had introduced this legislation.

The then opposition refused to pass it. They said, `No, we want to have a closer look at this.' Indeed, they said, `We are troubled by the idea of black letter law, so we will refer this off to a committee.' And that is what they did: they referred it off to the Reid committee. It is common ground, I think, amongst the parties that the work of the Reid committee was very good work, but it ought to be understood that in doing so the government failed when they were in opposition to support the legislation coming forward from the government. Equally, when we went into opposition Kim Beazley moved a private member's bill, the Trade Practices (Better Business Conduct) Bill, which would have addressed some of these concerns. The government did not move to implement that legislation, and I believe that it was most unfortunate that they failed to do that, for reasons that I will come to in a moment.

Before doing that, I want to support what the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) has said about the deficiencies of the bill. In particular, I want to express concern about the fact that the government has not moved on the idea of a uniform retail tenancy code. That is something which they have handballed off to the states. All the indications from the states are that they are not going to address it properly, and therefore one of the most important reforms for retail tenants, one of the things that would give them genuine access to justice and genuine avenues for redress, a retail tenancy tribunal, simply will not be there. For the minister to come into the parliament, as he did earlier on, and say, `Oh, what is being proposed is too different jurisdictions, a national and a state jurisdiction, and two different sets of tribunals' is nonsense. That is not what the committee recommended and it is not the opposition's position.

I think it is most unfortunate that the government has not moved to implement a uniform retail tenancy code and to establish a tribunal which would be able to give effect to that. What we have seen is a delay in bringing forward legislation, from the time that Labor moved on legislation in 1995 to the bill that is now before the House. (Extension of time granted) In the time that the government has not moved to bring this bill before the parliament and has been conducting this inquiry, there are a great many retail tenants who have suffered in the process and many people have gone out of business, have lost their life savings and, in the most extreme cases that have been brought to my attention, are now living in caravan parks and the like as a result. They are rightly concerned about the fact that there is nothing in this legislation which gives them any satisfaction or any compensation for the hardships that they have gone through. For example, I have received correspondence from Mrs Mary Caruana from the Ex Traders of Victoria saying:
We feel very strongly that `New Deal Fair Deal' is not new or fair. The meaning of the `unconscion able law' that is in the Trade Practices Act 1974, 51AA, means `duty of care'.

She goes on to say that the ex-traders have talked to politicians from both sides of the fence and that they have endeavoured to show that there has been a horrendous lack of duty of care, causing thousands of small business people, their homes, their families, their cash flow and their health to suffer, with more of this conduct still going on. She says:

We know that you all know that too, and that `New Deal Fair Deal' does not come close to fixing the problems that we have proven. We would like to let Mr Peter Reith know that the laws that he has introduced are not good enough to take the great pressures, stresses and losses that all of this has caused.
She raises the issue of compensation and security of tenure legislation.

I know that she and others in that group are so concerned about it that they have put together a petition of several thousand signatures from people who are concerned at the plight of the ex-traders. There are, I think, two petitions floating around. One, which comes from traders and ex-traders, says:

I want my voice to be heard. I call on the Federal Government to immediately implement the complete recommendations of the Fair Trading Inquiry, and to organise immediate compensation for ex-traders forced out of business through the misrepresentation and unconscionable conduct of landlords.

I know that the House has heard many cases of retail tenants who have suffered, but once again I think we need to hear about these things to bring home to people what the real impact on the lives of ordinary people this issue has. At the bottom of this particular petition I have, this chap from Epping Plaza says:

I'd like to inform you that I'm a well-educated person with qualifications in architecture and modern accounting who couldn't find a job. I hate to be unemployed, so I started my business, a gift shop. Now I work 65 hours a week to earn almost $150 a week. It is just unfair and unhuman; I feel like a slave working for somebody else who's taking all my profit. I've been in many European countries and haven't seen such a mess before.

This is the kind of situation that people who are in retail tenancies are suffering, and they are saying that they want the complete recommendations of the fair trading inquiry implemented, and that is the position that we in the opposition, we in the Labor Party, have taken. We believe that the complete recommendations ought to be implemented and we are disappointed that the government has failed to do this.

The other thing that ought to be said in relation to this debate is that there is a major role for the ACCC in acting on unconscionable conduct claims. I have been disappointed at what I have seen as a lack of action on their part in relation to this issue, but it is interesting to note that just recently they have instituted proceedings in the Federal Court in Perth concerning a particular shopping centre—

talk.start.para: —Farrington Fayre.

—Indeed, the member for Cunningham is correct. The ACCC alleges that in 1996 and early 1997 the owners implemented a strategy whereby they refused to grant renewals, variations or extensions of leases to three tenants unless those tenants withdrew from legal proceedings against the owners which were before the Western Australian Commercial Tenancy Tribunal, or agreed not to pursue legal rights against the owners. If that is the case, I think we would all agree that that is disgraceful conduct. The ACCC believes that those retail tenants were at a special disadvantage when bargaining with the owners because of their financial dependence upon renewal, variation or extension of their leases. (Extension of time granted) That is exactly right, and that is often the situation for retail tenants. Once you get into a shopping centre, and you have often paid a lot of money to get in there in the first place or have paid a lot of money to renovate and fit up the shop, you need to have your lease renewed. It is not a position of equal or comparable bargaining power. If you lose the lease—if it is not renewed or you are evicted—a great deal of your livelihood is lost in the process. So I am pleased to see that the ACCC is acting on unconscionable conduct issues, and I hope that in future we will see a lot more of that.

speech.para: To conclude, I support the remarks of the member for Cunningham. The opposition has played a very constructive role in this issue all the way along, trying to achieve justice for retail tenants; indeed, it drew to the attention of the parliament the conflict of interest problems surrounding the former minister for small business, the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser). I believe that if we had not done that, and if we had not secured his resignation, we would not have seen anything like that which we are seeing before the House today in terms of legislation to deal with this issue. Regrettably, when you examine the legislation closely there is somewhat less to it than meets the eye, and I believe that many of the concerns of retail tenants will continue into the future. But, in so far as the bill takes steps forward, they are welcomed by us and the legislation has our support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
